agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I would like to begin by paying tribute to the work of the chief inspector, in particular in relation to Birmingham, and indeed his entire inspection team.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The situation in HMP Birmingham was simply unacceptable.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It was shocking in terms of the levels of violence, in terms of the response to those levels of violence, in terms of the drugs, and in terms of basic decency.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The situation in Birmingham has of course been of considerable concern for some time; for that reason I visited personally in the week before the inspector issued the report.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The Secretary of State for Justice, the Lord Chancellor, also made a personal visit to Birmingham, and the chief executive of the Prison Service also visited Birmingham.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The reason for this is that over the last few weeks and months we have been increasingly concerned about G4S's inability to turn around the situation.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The steps we took were initially to issue a notice to improve, followed by a second notice to improve.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I then held meetings with G4S in London at which it replaced its governor-who had been in place for 18 months-and brought in a new governor.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It then brought in a new team; we came up with a new action plan and a new team was brought in by the Ministry to work alongside it.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Notwithstanding all the steps that Birmingham and G4S took over those months, the conclusion that we reluctantly reached in the week before the inspector published his urgent notification was that G4S would not be able on its own to turn around the significant problems of Birmingham.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Therefore the decision was made to take the unprecedented step of the Government stepping in and taking over control.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That means in effect three things.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: First, we have brought in a highly experienced governor from the public sector, Mr Paul Newton, who has taken over as the governor of the prison.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Secondly, we have reduced the number of prisoners in Birmingham prison by 300, which has allowed us to take key cells out of operation and renovate them.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Thirdly, we have brought in an additional 32 highly experienced public sector prison staff in order to support the team on the ground.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: All of this will be done with no cost to the taxpayer, and I want to take this opportunity also to say that, notwithstanding the very significant problems at Birmingham, there are dedicated, serious professional staff on the ground who have been facing a very difficult situation.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: There have been real challenges around drugs and leadership.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are confident that, with Paul Newton and the new team and the reduction in numbers, we can stabilise that prison, address the drugs and the violence, and turn it around and restore the confidence to the team.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I anticipate that this could rapidly become a debate over the merits or otherwise of privatisation, and I am expecting that the shadow Secretary of State will almost certainly go in that direction.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: For what it is worth, we on this side of the House do not believe that this is primarily an ideological battle.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The situation in Birmingham has been serious for some time.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It was a Labour Secretary of State for Justice who initially decided to proceed with the privatisation of Birmingham in 2010, although it was a Conservative Secretary of State who finally let the contract.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The company concerned, G4S, has clearly significantly failed in Birmingham, but at the same time, as Members such as the Member for Bridgend (Mrs Moon) can confirm, it is running an impressive prison in Parc and at Altcourse in Liverpool, which is performing well particularly in education and work, while Parc is doing well on family services.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The BBC has just produced a very positive report on its performance at Oakwood as well.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: So this is not primarily about the difference between the public and the private sectors.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Sadly, there have been significant challenges also within the public sector, at Nottingham prison, at Liverpool and at Exeter most recently.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Indeed the chief inspector of prisons himself underlined that this is not primarily about public against private, but is about basic issues primarily around drugs, violence and management.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We will be focusing on those three things above all through this step-in, and, as I have said, at no cost to the taxpayer.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I thank the shadow Secretary of State for Justice for his questions.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: They are serious questions, and this was a serious failing in that prison.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I shall try to answer them one by one.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The financial cost to G4S of us stepping in will be very considerable.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: G4S already estimates that it is losing on this contract.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It is to a great extent paid according to the number of prison places.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Specifically, therefore, the removal of 300 prisoners from that prison will impose a direct financial penalty on G4S, which will be covered by G4S itself.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I can also confirm that the entire cost of this step-in will be covered not by the taxpayer but by G4S, because we will withhold the payment we would normally make in line with the contract with G4S to cover those costs.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The shadow Secretary of State also asked whether we would put exactly 32 officers into the other challenged prisons.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are not in a position to specify the exact numbers, but the broad approach that we would take to Birmingham is the same as the approach that we would take to the other public sector prisons.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That approach involves focusing first on the inflow of drugs into those prisons, through the use of intelligence disruption for organised criminal groups as well as through the use of scanners.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are putting nearly Â£6 million-worth of investment into drug interdiction and scanners.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Secondly, our approach involves focusing on basic decency, and nearly Â£30 million-worth of extra investment is going into living conditions in our prisons.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Thirdly, there is a focus on education, and the Secretary of State's education and employment strategy is central to this, giving prisoners purposeful activity within the prison walls and ensuring that they get jobs on release, thereby reducing reoffending and protecting the public.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Finally, and perhaps most importantly of all, we are focusing on supporting our hard-working prison officers with the right training in leadership and management skills.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: They are doing an incredibly tough job outside prison doors.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: They are facing unprecedented levels of challenges with the new psychoactive substances coming in, and we really need to support them.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are doing that through the Assaults on Emergency Workers (Offences) Bill introduced by the Member for Rhondda (Chris Bryant) which will double the sentences for people who assault prison officers and other emergency workers.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are also doing it through additional training for prison officers before they go on the wings and supporting them through training as they continue.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The shadow Secretary of State asked about an independent commission.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Respectfully, I would argue that we already understand very well what happened at Birmingham Prison, without the need for an additional independent report.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The independent monitoring board has produced a full report on Birmingham Prison.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The chief inspector of prisons has also produced a full report, and we have looked closely at Birmingham Prison over the past few weeks and months.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Unfortunately, the story at Birmingham Prison is a relatively familiar one.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It is about drugs, about violence and about management and training.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: There is no great secret there.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The question of G4S bidding for future prison contracts is a hypothetical one, and no such contracts will be let for a number of years.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: However, we will of course, in accordance with all our rules, look seriously at the past record and performance of the companies involved, including G4S, before considering it for a tender.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: The Minister and the Secretary of State are to be commended on their prompt action.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: The Minister should be commended on his swift involvement, and I thank him for contacting me, as the Chair of the Justice Committee, so quickly.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: Does he agree that no pattern emerges in the evidence to show that there is any distinction between the problems that arise in our prisons that relates to the public or private nature of their ownership and management?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: Two patterns do emerge, however.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: One is a consistent history of failure in our old Victorian local prisons, be they run by the public or private sector, and the second is a persistent failure by the Prison Service, whether acting directly or through contract, to act upon the recommendations of Her Majesty's inspectorate of prisons-a litany that has been picked up by the chief inspector.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Bob Neill
sentences: What are the Government going to do to address those two clear patterns of failure?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I will take those two matters separately.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: As for responding to the inspector's recommendations, we have changed-the Secretary of State for Justice has driven this through-how our management systems work to put the inspector's recommendations and reports at the heart of the way we set objectives for the Prison Service.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We had our own independent assessment under the previous system, but we expect the House to see that how we manage prisons much more closely reflects inspection reports in the future.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: On the question of old Victorian buildings, there clearly is a pattern, but it is not an absolute pattern.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: There are old buildings, such as Stafford, that are well run, good prisons, and there are new prisons, such as Nottingham, that have managed to get themselves into trouble despite the new buildings.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: However, generally speaking, running an old Victorian prison adds to the problems, and we should ensure that our investment in 10,000 new places endeavours to remove the worst-affected prisons from our system.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I genuinely pay tribute to some of the things that are happening in Scotland in relation to prisons, and I was privileged to visit HMP Perth, which is a good example of a busy, challenged local prison that is being run well.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Prison officers in Scotland would also say that there have been significant cuts to their numbers since the early 2000s, and they, too, have had to make serious efficiency savings, which they have done well, and they are running good prisons.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We are watching closely what is happening on short sentences in Scotland.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Like the Scottish Government, our priority is to protect the public, but the evidence on what could be done to reduce reoffending by not overusing short prison sentences inappropriately is a good lesson from Scotland, from which we wish to learn.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Desmond Swayne
sentences: Prisoners who are at leisure to consume and trade Spice would benefit from penal servitude with hard labour.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Desmond Swayne
sentences: Will the Minister bring it back?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: No.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The Gentleman is absolutely right that it is about staff.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We now have 3,000 more prison officers than we had when we made the announcement, and having more staff will make a difference.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The next stage is getting the training right, particularly the training for the band 5 and band 4 uniformed staff who are out there on the landings day in, day out.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It is about getting the staff college right for governors, and it is also about making sure that, in places like our Newbold Revel training college, we have the right support for our prison officers.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It is an amazing profession, but it needs support and training.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Ed Vaizey
sentences: I agree with the Minister that this is not a debate about privatised versus publicly run prisons; obviously it is about how we work to ensure that we do not have such trouble again.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Ed Vaizey
sentences: I echo what my Friend the Member for Bromley and Chislehurst (Robert Neill), the Chairman of the Select Committee on Justice, said about the need to carry on the vision of reinvigorating the prison estate.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Ed Vaizey
sentences: I also echo the Minister's comments about education.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Ed Vaizey
sentences: The great opportunity in our prisons is to work with prisoners and to use, for example, culture and sport to give them opportunities.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Ed Vaizey
sentences: Prisons are often dealing with people who have mental health issues and, sometimes, a lack of education, and it has been shown that the arts and sport can do a great deal to help rehabilitate prisoners, as opposed to, say, penal servitude.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: My right Friend encourages me to reflect on our sport strategy, which is coming through.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Broadly speaking, there is also the key point about how education changes lives.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: By changing lives and helping people to get employment when they leave prison, education reduces reoffending and protects the public.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Stabilising our prisons and delivering high-quality education in prisons is good not just for prisoners but for the rest of society.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That is a very shocking, very immediate illustration of just how horrifying what was happening at Birmingham was.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The right Gentleman is right that, when something like that happens, not only should we take back control from G4S but we should think very seriously before returning the prison to it.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That is why, for exactly the reasons he raises, we are giving the House the assurance that we will be taking over for a minimum of six months-that is a minimum of six months -and we will be very tough and clear in the decisions we reach at the end of those six months on whether we believe the prison is stable enough to be handed back to G4S.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Victoria Prentis
sentences: Following on from the previous question, does my Friend agree that this debate is not about public or private management of prisons but is, in fact, about when it is appropriate for the Government to step in when prisons are failing?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Victoria Prentis
sentences: If I may say so, this debate is also about when it is appropriate for a Minister to take responsibility for the Prison Service, as I was pleased to read over the summer that he is willing to do.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Without getting dragged into an ideological discussion about public versus private, hopefully both sides of the House can agree that, if we are to have privatised systems, the best way for them to operate is by having the right degree of Government regulation and intervention when things go wrong.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Whether we are talking about water, utilities or, indeed, prisons, we cannot have a system in which the Government do not have a clear grip.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I hope stepping in at Birmingham demonstrates that the Government are prepared to do that when we reach this situation.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The rebuke is taken; of course it is true that, as with any institution, it is easier to run this with more staff and fewer people.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: But the answer in practice is that we take this remedy to stabilise a prison that has reached a situation that Birmingham has reached.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Once the prison is stabilised and functioning well, it is possible to run it with the full population.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We can see that being done at Altcourse and Thameside, and at a busy, challenged local prison such as HMP Hull at the moment.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: But it is necessary to take these steps at Birmingham, and the right Gentleman is right to say that it does not take a massive brain to work out that this is the first thing we need to do.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: John Howell
sentences: How will the Minister ensure that the new governor has both the powers and the support to carry out the reform of the prison?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Again, this is a good challenge.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It comes down to reasserting, in every way, both here in the House and through the management chain, that the governor is in charge, that we will give them the resources to get behind them and that we will support them in what they are doing.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It is absolutely right to say that only with a properly empowered governor are we going to achieve that change.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: This is a good challenge.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Birmingham was challenged, and we were focused on that situation.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That is why we had put in notices to improve, why we had negotiated to bring in a new governor and why we had put in a new team.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: A judgment had to be made as to the point at which we decided that G4S did not have the capacity to turn things around on its own and we had to step in.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: I think we were correct in taking a number of steps before we formally stepped in, but the Lady is absolutely right to challenge whether we could have done this a little earlier or a little later.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: That, in the end, was the judgment call we had to make.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Mike Wood
sentences: How many prisons have triggered urgent notifications since the system was introduced at the end of last year?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Mike Wood
sentences: How does that number break down between privately managed prisons and those run by the public sector?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The inspector has clarified that so far this year the prisons that have triggered urgent notification have been Exeter and Nottingham, and that he would have triggered a UN on Liverpool.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Birmingham is the fourth, so the answer is: three out of the four since the beginning of this year have been from the public sector.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The situation at Nottingham Prison has been very concerning, with deaths at the prison of particular concern.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We now have a new governor; a very highly respected, professional governor has come in.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Tom Wheatley, the previous governor, is moving on to another role.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We would expect to see the beginning of a turnaround there within the next six months, with the things to look at in particular being the statistics on drugs and violence.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Gordon Henderson
sentences: Paul Newton is an excellent governor.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Gordon Henderson
sentences: He was transferred from Swaleside prison, in my constituency-a prison that has its own problems.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Gordon Henderson
sentences: What assurances can the Minister give me that the transfer of Mr Newton will not be detrimental to my local prison?

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We have to be cognisant of that, but the Prison Service is a large system.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We have more than 20,000 prison officers, so although moving 32 staff will challenge some of the prisons from which they are removed, this should be accommodated within our prisons system.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We have a lot of other talented governors, and we remain confident that the need in Birmingham is greater than that at Swaleside.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: We will make sure that Paul Newton is replaced with a highly effective governor.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: The fundamental factor that triggered the change at Birmingham was that in December 2016 one of the prison officers managed to lose their keys, which led to nearly 200 prisoners being unlocked and a riot in the prison.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: G4S had been improving the prison over the previous three years, but that event really knocked the bottom out of it.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: It had a devastating effect on morale, and as the Lady implied, it led to a lot of experienced staff leaving the prison.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Rory Stewart
sentences: Looking back over that period, we can see that, although the chief inspector of prisons and the Government had hoped that things were beginning to improve during 2017, that turned out in the end to be a false promise, and we are still recovering from the blow of that December 2016 event.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Richard Drax
sentences: I have huge confidence in my Friend the Minister, but I do not have confidence that the prison officers that the Government employ will stay on.

agenda: HMP Birmingham
speaker: Richard Drax
sentences: The facts speak for themselves.
